When you insert text directly at the place where a marker points, there are two possible ways to relocate that marker: it can point before the inserted text, or point after it. You can specify which one a given marker should do by setting its insertion type. Note that use of insert-before-markers ignores markers’ insertion types, always relocating a marker to point after the inserted text.
When you introduce a new group into Emacs, use the :version keyword in the defgroup; then you need not use it for the individual members of the group.

When you load or reload files, bear in mind that the load and load-library functions automatically load a byte-compiled file rather than a non-compiled file of similar name. If you rewrite a file that you intend to save and reinstall, you need to byte-compile the new version; otherwise Emacs will load the older, byte-compiled file instead of your newer, non-compiled file! If that happens, the message displayed when loading the file includes, ‘

When you move to this item with widget-forward or widget-backward, it will display the string motion-doc in the echo area. In addition, motion-doc is used as the mouse help-echo string and may actually be a function or form evaluated to yield a help string. If it is a function, it is called with one argument, the widget.

When you need to modify a function defined in another library, or when you need to modify a hook like foo-function, a process filter, or basically any variable or object field which holds a function value, you can use the appropriate setter function, such as fset or defun for named functions, setq for hook variables, or set-process-filter for process filters, but those are often too blunt, completely throwing away the previous value.

When you run Emacs, it enters the editor command loop almost immediately. This loop reads key sequences, executes their definitions, and displays the results. In this chapter, we describe how these things are done, and the subroutines that allow Lisp programs to do them.

When you signal an error, you specify an error symbol to specify the kind of error you have in mind. Each error has one and only one error symbol to categorize it. This is the finest classification of errors defined by the Emacs Lisp language.
When you start Emacs, it normally attempts to load your init file. This is either a file named
When you use :group in a defgroup, it makes the new group a subgroup of group.
When you use compute-motion for the minibuffer, you need to use minibuffer-prompt-width to get the horizontal position of the beginning of the first screen line. See Minibuffer Contents.

When you use frame-parameter to query the value of either of these two frame parameters, the return value is always an integer. When using set-frame-parameter, passing a nil value imposes an actual default value of 8 pixels.
When you use the read syntax ‘

When you visit a file whose expanded file name (see File Name Expansion), with version numbers and backup suffixes removed using file-name-sans-versions (see File Name Components), matches a regexp, set-auto-mode calls the corresponding mode-function. This feature enables Emacs to select the proper major mode for most files.

When you want to get rid of a window used for displaying a buffer, you can call delete-window or delete-windows-on (see Deleting Windows) to remove that window from its frame. If the buffer is shown on a separate frame, you might want to call delete-frame (see Deleting Frames) instead. If, on the other hand, a window has been reused for displaying the buffer, you might prefer showing the buffer previously shown in that window, by calling the function switch-to-prev-buffer (see Window History). Finally, you might want to either bury (see Buffer List) or kill (see Killing Buffers) the window’s buffer.

When you write a list as an expression in your program, you specify which function to call, and how many arguments to give it, in the text of the program. Usually that’s just what you want. Occasionally you need to compute at run time which function to call. To do that, use the function funcall. When you also need to determine at run time how many arguments to pass, use apply.

When you write a selectively displayed buffer into a file, all the control-m’s are output as newlines. This means that when you next read in the file, it looks OK, with nothing hidden. The selective display effect is seen only within Emacs.

When your program encounters invalid input data, it can either signal a Lisp error by calling error or signal or report a warning with severity :error. Signaling a Lisp error is the easiest thing to do, but it means the program cannot continue processing. If you want to take the trouble to implement a way to continue processing despite the bad data, then reporting a warning of severity :error is the right way to inform the user of the problem. For instance, the Emacs Lisp byte compiler can report an error that way and continue compiling other functions. (If the program signals a Lisp error and then handles it with condition-case, the user won’t see the error message; it could show the message to the user by reporting it as a warning.)
Whenever Edebug is entered, it needs to save and restore certain data before even deciding whether to make trace information or stop the program.

Whenever Emacs starts up, it automatically calls the function package-activate-all to make installed packages available to the current session. This is done after loading the early init file, but before loading the regular init file (see Startup Summary). Packages are not automatically made available if the user option package-enable-at-startup is set to nil in the early init file.

Whenever Font Lock mode performs syntactic fontification on a stretch of text, it first calls the function specified by syntax-propertize-function. Major modes can use this to apply syntax-table text properties to override the buffer’s syntax table in special cases. See Syntax Properties.
Whenever you change the sort direction in Tabulated List buffers, this indicator toggles between ascending (“asc”) and descending (“desc”).

Where a <var>button</var> parameter is specified, it means an object referring to a specific button, either an overlay (for overlay buttons), or a buffer-position or marker (for text property buttons). Such an object is passed as the first argument to a button’s invocation function when it is invoked.
Where doc strings are defined and stored.
Where exactly paragraphs start and end, for the purpose of the Emacs
Where removed text sometimes is saved for later use.

Whether a child frame can have a menu or tool bar is window-system or window manager dependent. Most window-systems explicitly disallow menu bars for child frames. It seems advisable to disable both, menu and tool bars, via the frame’s initial parameters settings.
Whether or not a box should be drawn around characters, its color, the width of the box lines, and 3D appearance. Here are the possible values of the :box attribute, and what they mean:
Whether or not characters should be displayed in inverse video. The value should be t (yes) or nil (no).

Whether or not characters should be overlined, and in what color. If the value is t, overlining uses the foreground color of the face. If the value is a string, overlining uses that color. The value nil means do not overline.
Whether or not characters should be strike-through, and in what color. The value is used like that of :overline.
Whether or not characters should be underlined, and in what way. The possible values of the :underline attribute are:
Whether or not the terminal can display the face attributes given in value… (see Face Attributes). See Display Face Attribute Testing, for more information on exactly how this testing is done.

Whether or not this face will be extended beyond end of line and will affect the display of the empty space between the end of line and the edge of the window. The value should be t to display the empty space between end of line and edge of the window using this face, or nil to not use this face for the space between the end of the line and the edge of the window. When Emacs merges several faces for displaying the empty space beyond end of line, only those faces with :extend non-nil will be merged. By default, only a small number of faces, notably, region, have this attribute set. This attribute is different from the others in that when a theme doesn’t specify an explicit value for a face, the value from the original face definition by defface is inherited (see Defining Faces).
Whether or not to pause for edebug-sit-for-seconds on reaching a breakpoint. Set to nil to prevent the pause, non-nil to allow it.
Whether recursive entry to minibuffer is allowed.
Whether the action renamed is returned, depends on the used watch library. Otherwise, the actions deleted and created could be returned in a random order.
Whether the frame has scroll bars (see Scroll Bars) for vertical scrolling, and which side of the frame they should be on. The possible values are left, right, and nil for no scroll bars.
Whether the frame has scroll bars for horizontal scrolling (t and bottom mean yes, nil means no).

Whether the menu bar is wrapped or truncated whenever its width becomes too large to fit on its frame depends on the toolkit . Usually, only Motif and MS-Windows builds can wrap the menu bar. When they (un-)wrap the menu bar, they try to keep the outer height of the frame unchanged, so the native height of the frame (see below) will change instead.

Whether this frame has its own minibuffer. The value t means yes, nil means no, only means this frame is just a minibuffer. If the value is a minibuffer window (in some other frame), the frame uses that minibuffer.
Whether to query if exiting will kill a process.
Which File Defined a Certain Symbol
Which buffer is current, and the positions of point and the mark in the current buffer, are saved and restored.
Which buffers have been or should be shown.
Which character sets are used in a buffer?
Which parameters are accepted by the notification server can be checked via notifications-get-capabilities.
Which window system is being used.

While a sentinel is running, the process sentinel is temporarily set to nil so that the sentinel won’t run recursively. For this reason it is not possible for a sentinel to specify a new sentinel.

While a sentinel or filter function is running, this function returns non-nil if Emacs was waiting for keyboard input from the user at the time the sentinel or filter function was called, or nil if it was not.
While executing or tracing, you can interrupt the execution by typing any Edebug command. Edebug stops the program at the next stop point and then executes the command you typed. For example, typing

While global variables are shared among all Emacs Lisp threads, local variables are not—a dynamic let binding is local. Each thread also has its own current buffer (see Current Buffer) and its own match data (see Match Data).

While in Edebug, you can set a breakpoint with

While this function is mainly intended for use in auto-reverting, it could be used for other purposes as well. For instance, if auto-reverting is not enabled, it could be used to warn the user that the buffer needs reverting. The idea behind the noconfirm argument is that it should be t if the buffer is going to be reverted without asking the user and nil if the function is just going to be used to warn the user that the buffer is out of date. In particular, for use in auto-reverting, noconfirm is t. If the function is only going to be used for auto-reverting, you can ignore the noconfirm argument.
trans-unit.target: Si bien esta función está diseñada principalmente para su uso en la reversión automática, también podría usarse para otros fines. Por ejemplo, si la reversión automática no está habilitada, podría usarse para advertir al usuario que el búfer debe revertirse. La idea detrás del argumento noconfirm es que debería ser t si el búfer se va a revertir sin preguntar al usuario y nil si la función solo se usará para advertir al usuario que el búfer está desactualizado. En particular, para su uso en noconfirm automática, noconfirm es t . Si la función solo se va a utilizar para la noconfirm automática, puede ignorar el argumento noconfirm .

trans-unit.source: While using Edebug, you can specify breakpoints in the program you are testing: these are places where execution should stop. You can set a breakpoint at any stop point, as defined in Using Edebug. For setting and unsetting breakpoints, the stop point that is affected is the first one at or after point in the source code buffer. Here are the Edebug commands for breakpoints:
trans-unit.target: Mientras usa Edebug, puede especificar puntos de interrupción en el programa que está probando: estos son lugares donde la ejecución debería detenerse. Puede establecer un punto de interrupción en cualquier punto de parada, como se define en Uso de Edebug . Para configurar y desarmar puntos de interrupción, el punto de parada que se ve afectado es el primero en o después del punto en el búfer de código fuente. Aquí están los comandos de Edebug para puntos de interrupción:

trans-unit.source: While window change functions are run, the functions described next can be called to get more insight into what has changed for a specific window or frame since the last redisplay. All these functions take a live window as single, optional argument, defaulting to the selected window.
trans-unit.target: Mientras se ejecutan las funciones de cambio de ventana,las funciones descritas a continuacin pueden ser llamadas para obtener ms informacin sobre lo que ha cambiado para una ventana o marco especfico desde la ltima reimpresin.Todas estas funciones toman una ventana en vivo como argumento nico y opcional,predeterminando la ventana seleccionada.

trans-unit.source: While within Edebug, you can evaluate expressions as if Edebug were not running. Edebug tries to be invisible to the expression’s evaluation and printing. Evaluation of expressions that cause side effects will work as expected, except for changes to data that Edebug explicitly saves and restores. See The Outside Context, for details on this process.
trans-unit.target: Mientras está dentro de Edebug, puede evaluar expresiones como si Edebug no se estuviera ejecutando. Edebug intenta ser invisible a la evaluación e impresión de la expresión. La evaluación de expresiones que causan efectos secundarios funcionará como se esperaba, excepto por los cambios en los datos que Edebug guarda y restaura explícitamente. Consulte El contexto externo para obtener detalles sobre este proceso.

trans-unit.target: Los caracteres de los espacios en blanco antes y despus de las comas son ignorados.
Caracteres de espacio en blanco: '' o '

Tipo de configuracin de la ventana
Parmetros del marco de la ventana
Lneas de encabezamiento de la ventana

trans-unit.source: Window change functions are called during redisplay for each frame as follows: First, any buffer-local window buffer change function, window size change function, selected window change and window state change functions are called in this order. Next, the default values for these functions are called in the same order. Then any buffer-local window configuration change functions are called followed by functions specified by the default value of those functions. Finally, functions on window-state-change-hook are run.
trans-unit.target: Las funciones de cambio de ventana se llaman durante la nueva visualización para cada cuadro de la siguiente manera: Primero, cualquier función de cambio de búfer de ventana local de búfer, función de cambio de tamaño de ventana, cambio de ventana seleccionada y funciones de cambio de estado de ventana se llaman en este orden. A continuación, los valores predeterminados para estas funciones se llaman en el mismo orden. Luego, cualquier función de cambio de configuración de la ventana local del búfer se llama seguida de funciones especificadas por el valor predeterminado de esas funciones. Por último, se ejecutan las funciones en window-state-change-hook .

trans-unit.source: Window change functions are run for a specific frame only if a corresponding change was registered for that frame earlier. Such changes include the creation or deletion of a window or the assignment of another buffer or size to a window. Note that even when such a change has been registered, this does not mean that any of the hooks described above is run. If, for example, a change was registered within the scope of a window excursion (see Window Configurations), this will trigger a call of window change functions only if that excursion still persists at the time change functions are run. If it is exited earlier, hooks will be run only if registered by a change outside the scope of that excursion.
trans-unit.target: Las funciones de cambio de ventana se ejecutan para un marco específico solo si se registró un cambio correspondiente para ese marco antes. Dichos cambios incluyen la creación o eliminación de una ventana o la asignación de otro búfer o tamaño a una ventana. Tenga en cuenta que incluso cuando se haya registrado dicho cambio, esto no significa que se ejecute ninguno de los enlaces descritos anteriormente. Si, por ejemplo, se registró un cambio dentro del alcance de una excursión de ventana (consulte Configuraciones de ventana ), esto activará una llamada de funciones de cambio de ventana solo si esa excursión aún persiste en el momento en que se ejecutan las funciones de cambio. Si se sale antes, los ganchos se ejecutarán solo si se registran mediante un cambio fuera del alcance de esa excursión.

trans-unit.source: Window change functions should not create or delete windows or change the buffer, size or selection status of any window because there is no guarantee that the information about such a change will be propagated to other window change functions. If at all, any such change should be executed only by the last function listed by the default value of window-state-change-hook.
trans-unit.target: Las funciones de cambio de ventana no deben crear ni eliminar ventanas ni cambiar el búfer, el tamaño o el estado de selección de ninguna ventana porque no hay garantía de que la información sobre dicho cambio se propague a otras funciones de cambio de ventana. En todo caso, dicho cambio debe ser ejecutado solo por la última función listada por el valor predeterminado de window-state-change-hook .

trans-unit.source: Window configurations do not have a read syntax; their print syntax looks like ‘
trans-unit.target: Las configuraciones de ventana no tienen sintaxis de lectura; su sintaxis de impresión se parece a '

trans-unit.source: Window dividers are bars drawn between a frame’s windows. A right divider is drawn between a window and any adjacent windows on the right. Its width (thickness) is specified by the frame parameter right-divider-width. A bottom divider is drawn between a window and adjacent windows on the bottom or the echo area. Its width is specified by the frame parameter bottom-divider-width. In either case, specifying a width of zero means to not draw such dividers. See Layout Parameters.
trans-unit.target: Los divisores de ventana son barras dibujadas entre las ventanas de un marco. Se dibuja un divisor derecho entre una ventana y cualquier ventana adyacente a la derecha. Su ancho (grosor) se especifica mediante el parámetro de marco right-divider-width . Se dibuja un divisor inferior entre una ventana y ventanas adyacentes en la parte inferior o en el área de eco. Su ancho se especifica mediante el parámetro de marco bottom-divider-width . En cualquier caso, especificar un ancho de cero significa no dibujar tales divisores. Consulte Parámetros de diseño .

trans-unit.source: Window managers generally heed user-specified positions, and some heed program-specified positions too. But many ignore program-specified positions, placing the window in a default fashion or letting the user place it with the mouse. Some window managers, including twm, let the user specify whether to obey program-specified positions or ignore them.
trans-unit.target: Los administradores de ventanas generalmente prestan atención a las posiciones especificadas por el usuario, y algunos también prestan atención a las posiciones especificadas por el programa. Pero muchos ignoran las posiciones especificadas por el programa, colocando la ventana de forma predeterminada o dejando que el usuario la coloque con el mouse. Algunos administradores de ventanas, incluido twm , permiten al usuario especificar si obedecer las posiciones especificadas por el programa o ignorarlas.

trans-unit.source: Window managers might not bother to extend their focus follows mouse policy to child frames. Customizing mouse-autoselect-window can help in this regard (see Mouse Window Auto-selection).
trans-unit.target: Es posible que los administradores de ventanas no se molesten en extender su enfoque según la política del mouse a los marcos secundarios. Personalizar la mouse-autoselect-window puede ayudar a este respecto (consulte Selección automática de la ventana del mouse ).

trans-unit.source: Window systems provide general ways for the user to control which window gets keyboard input. This choice of window is called the focus. When the user does something to switch between Emacs frames, that generates a focus event. The normal definition of a focus event, in the global keymap, is to select a new frame within Emacs, as the user would expect. See Input Focus, which also describes hooks related to focus events.
trans-unit.target: Los sistemas de ventanas proporcionan formas generales para que el usuario controle qué ventana recibe la entrada del teclado. Esta elección de ventana se llama foco . Cuando el usuario hace algo para cambiar entre marcos de Emacs, eso genera un evento de enfoque . La definición normal de un evento de enfoque, en el mapa de teclas global, es seleccionar un nuevo marco dentro de Emacs, como esperaría el usuario. Consulte Input Focus , que también describe los ganchos relacionados con los eventos de enfoque.

trans-unit.source: Windows are grouped into frames (see Frames). Each frame contains at least one window; the user can subdivide it into multiple, non-overlapping windows to view several buffers at once. Lisp programs can use multiple windows for a variety of purposes. In Rmail, for example, you can view a summary of message titles in one window, and the contents of the selected message in another window.
trans-unit.target: Las ventanas se agrupan en marcos (consulte Marcos ). Cada marco contiene al menos una ventana; el usuario puede subdividirlo en varias ventanas que no se superponen para ver varios búferes a la vez. Los programas Lisp pueden usar múltiples ventanas para una variedad de propósitos. En Rmail, por ejemplo, puede ver un resumen de los títulos de los mensajes en una ventana y el contenido del mensaje seleccionado en otra ventana.

trans-unit.source: Windows are grouped on the screen into frames; each window belongs to one and only one frame. See Frame Type.
trans-unit.target: Las ventanas se agrupan en la pantalla en marcos; cada ventana pertenece a un solo marco. Consulte Tipo de estructura .

trans-unit.source: Windows have no read syntax. They print in hash notation, giving the window number and the name of the buffer being displayed. The window numbers exist to identify windows uniquely, since the buffer displayed in any given window can change frequently.
trans-unit.target: Las ventanas no tienen sintaxis de lectura.Se imprimen en notacin hash,dando el nmero de la ventana y el nombre del buffer que se muestra.Los nmeros de ventana existen para identificar las ventanas de manera nica,ya que el buffer que se muestra en una ventana determinada puede cambiar con frecuencia.

trans-unit.source: Windows icon file. If <var>icon</var> is not a string, or if this parameter is not specified, the standard Emacs icon will be used.
trans-unit.target: Archivo de icono de Windows. Si el <var>icon</var> o no es una cadena, o si no se especifica este parámetro, se utilizará el icono estándar de Emacs.

trans-unit.source: Windows in the same frame are organized into a window tree, whose leaf nodes are the live windows. The internal nodes of a window tree are not live; they exist for the purpose of organizing the relationships between live windows. The root node of a window tree is called the root window. It can be either a live window (if the frame has just one window), or an internal window.
trans-unit.target: Las ventanas en el mismo marco se organizan en un árbol de ventanas , cuyos nodos hoja son las ventanas en vivo. Los nodos internos de un árbol de ventana no están activos; existen con el propósito de organizar las relaciones entre ventanas en vivo. El nodo raíz de un árbol de ventana se denomina ventana raíz . Puede ser una ventana en vivo (si el marco tiene solo una ventana) o una ventana interna.

trans-unit.source: With cl-case, you would need to explicitly declare a local variable code to hold the return value of get-return-code. Also cl-case is difficult to use with strings because it uses eql for comparison.
trans-unit.target: Con cl-case , necesitaría declarar explícitamente un code variable local para contener el valor de retorno de get-return-code . Además, cl-case es difícil de usar con cadenas porque usa eql para comparar.

trans-unit.source: With Emacs, you can have a drag event without even changing your clothes. A drag event happens every time the user presses a mouse button and then moves the mouse to a different character position before releasing the button. Like all mouse events, drag events are represented in Lisp as lists. The lists record both the starting mouse position and the final position, like this:

Un evento de arrastre ocurre cada vez que el usuario presiona un botón del mouse y luego mueve el mouse a una posición de carácter diferente antes de soltar el botón. Como todos los eventos del mouse, los eventos de arrastre se representan en Lisp como listas. Las listas registran tanto la posición inicial del mouse como la posición final, así:

trans-unit.source: With a prefix argument <var>n</var>, the temporary breakpoint is placed <var>n</var> sexps beyond point. If the containing list ends before <var>n</var> more elements, then the place to stop is after the containing expression.
trans-unit.target: Con un argumento de prefijo <var>n</var> , el punto de interrupción temporal se coloca <var>n</var> sexps más allá del punto. Si la lista contenedora termina antes de <var>n</var> elementos más, entonces el lugar para detenerse es después de la expresión contenedora.

trans-unit.target: Con un argumento de 0, incondicionalmente no realice ningún archivo de respaldo.

trans-unit.source: With an argument of zero, recenter positions the current line at the top of the window. The command recenter-top-bottom offers a more convenient way to achieve this.
trans-unit.target: Con un argumento de cero, recenter coloca la línea actual en la parte superior de la ventana. El comando recenter-top-bottom ofrece una forma más conveniente de lograr esto.

trans-unit.source: With one or more <var>divisors</var>, this function divides <var>number</var> by each divisor in <var>divisors</var> in turn, and returns the quotient. With no <var>divisors</var>, this function returns 1/<var>number</var>, i.e., the multiplicative inverse of <var>number</var>. Each argument may be a number or a marker.
trans-unit.target: Con uno o más <var>divisors</var> , esta función divide el <var>number</var> por cada divisor en <var>divisors</var> a su vez y devuelve el cociente. Sin <var>divisors</var> , esta función devuelve 1 / <var>number</var> , es decir, el inverso multiplicativo del <var>number</var> . Cada argumento puede ser un número o un marcador.

trans-unit.source: With rare exceptions, the only reasonable way to use make-variable-buffer-local in a Lisp package is for a variable which is used only within that package. Using it on a variable used by other packages would interfere with them.
trans-unit.target: Con raras excepciones, la única forma razonable de usar make-variable-buffer-local en un paquete Lisp es para una variable que se usa solo dentro de ese paquete. Usarlo en una variable usada por otros paquetes interferiría con ellos.

trans-unit.source: With some window managers you may have to customize the variable frame-resize-pixelwise (see Frame Size) in order to make a frame truly appear maximized or full-screen. Moreover, some window managers might not support smooth transition between the various full-screen or maximization states. Customizing the variable x-frame-normalize-before-maximize can help to overcome that.
trans-unit.target: Con algunos administradores de ventanas, es posible que tenga que personalizar la variable frame-resize-pixelwise (consulte Tamaño de marco ) para que un marco parezca realmente maximizado o en pantalla completa. Además, es posible que algunos administradores de ventanas no admitan una transición fluida entre los distintos estados de pantalla completa o maximización. Personalizar la variable x-frame-normalize-before-maximize puede ayudar a superar eso.

trans-unit.source: With some window managers you may have to set this to non-nil in order to make a frame appear truly maximized or full-screen.
trans-unit.target: Con algunos administradores de ventanas, es posible que tenga que establecer esto en no nil para que un marco parezca realmente maximizado o en pantalla completa.

trans-unit.source: Within Edebug, the recursion depth appears one deeper than the recursion depth outside Edebug. This is not true of the automatically updated evaluation list window.
trans-unit.target: Dentro de Edebug,la profundidad de recursividad aparece una ms profunda que la profundidad de recursividad fuera de Edebug.Esto no es cierto en la ventana de la lista de evaluacin actualizada automticamente.

trans-unit.source: Within Edebug, you normally view an Emacs buffer showing the source of the Lisp code you are debugging. This is referred to as the source code buffer, and it is temporarily read-only.
trans-unit.target: Dentro de Edebug, normalmente ve un búfer de Emacs que muestra la fuente del código Lisp que está depurando. Esto se conoce como el búfer de código fuente y es temporalmente de solo lectura.

trans-unit.source: Within a macro definition, you can use the declare form (see Defining Macros) to specify how
trans-unit.target: Dentro de una definición de macro, puede utilizar el formulario de declare (consulte Definición de macros ) para especificar cómo

trans-unit.source: Within the function For itself, the local variable args refers to objects controlled by Emacs’s stack-marking garbage collector. Although the garbage collector does not reclaim objects reachable from C Lisp_Object stack variables, it may move some of the components of an object, such as the contents of a string or the text of a buffer. Therefore, functions that access these components must take care to refetch their addresses after performing Lisp evaluation. This means that instead of keeping C pointers to string contents or buffer text, the code should keep the buffer or string position, and recompute the C pointer from the position after performing Lisp evaluation. Lisp evaluation can occur via calls to eval_sub or Feval, either directly or indirectly.
trans-unit.target: Dentro de la función For sí misma, la variable local args se refiere a objetos controlados por el recolector de basura de marcado de pila de Emacs. Aunque el recolector de basura no recupera objetos accesibles desde las variables de pila C Lisp_Object , puede mover algunos de los componentes de un objeto, como el contenido de una cadena o el texto de un búfer. Por lo tanto, las funciones que acceden a estos componentes deben tener cuidado de recuperar sus direcciones después de realizar la evaluación Lisp. Esto significa que en lugar de mantener los punteros C al contenido de la cadena o al texto del búfer, el código debe mantener la posición del búfer o de la cadena y volver a calcular el puntero C desde la posición después de realizar la evaluación Lisp. La evaluación Lisp puede ocurrir mediante llamadas a eval_sub o Feval , ya sea directa o indirectamente.

trans-unit.source: Writing a good indentation function can be difficult and to a large extent it is still a black art. Many major mode authors will start by writing a simple indentation function that works for simple cases, for example by comparing with the indentation of the previous text line. For most programming languages that are not really line-based, this tends to scale very poorly: improving such a function to let it handle more diverse situations tends to become more and more difficult, resulting in the end with a large, complex, unmaintainable indentation function which nobody dares to touch.
trans-unit.target: Escribir una buena funcin de indentacin puede ser difcil y en gran medida sigue siendo un arte negro.Muchos autores de modos principales comenzarn escribiendo una funcin de indentacin simple que funciona para casos sencillos,por ejemplo,comparando la indentacin de la lnea de texto anterior.En la mayora de los lenguajes de programacin que no se basan realmente en lneas,esto tiende a escalar muy mal:mejorar tal funcin para que pueda manejar situaciones ms diversas tiende a ser cada vez ms difcil,lo que resulta al final en una funcin de indentacin grande,compleja e insostenible que nadie se atreve a tocar.

trans-unit.source: X resource settings typically apply to all frames. If you want to specify some X resources solely for the sake of the initial frame, and you don’t want them to apply to subsequent frames, here’s how to achieve this. Specify parameters in default-frame-alist to override the X resources for subsequent frames; then, to prevent these from affecting the initial frame, specify the same parameters in initial-frame-alist with values that match the X resources.
trans-unit.target: La configuración de recursos X normalmente se aplica a todos los marcos. Si desea especificar algunos recursos X únicamente por el bien del fotograma inicial, y no quiere que se apliquen a los fotogramas posteriores, aquí le mostramos cómo hacerlo. Especifique parámetros en default-frame-alist para anular los recursos X para los marcos posteriores; luego, para evitar que afecten a la trama inicial, especifique los mismos parámetros en initial-frame-alist con valores que coincidan con los recursos X.
